name: mate
content:
mate

noun
 
 
/meɪt/
 
/meɪt/
jump to other results

    friend

  1. ​
     
    [countable] (British English, Australian English, informal) a friend
    • They've been best mates since school.
    • I was with a mate.
    Wordfinder
    • acquaintance
    • bond
    • buddy
    • companion
    • comrade
    • friend
    • mate
    • neighbour
    • platonic
    • playmate
    Extra Examples
    • He's a cheat and a gambler; hardly an ideal mate.
    • He's got loads of mates at school.
    Topics Family and relationshipsb2
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • best
    • good
    verb + mate
    • have
    See full entry
    2.

    friendly name

  2. ​
     
    [countable] (British English, Australian English, informal) used as a friendly way of addressing somebody, especially between men
    • Sorry mate, you'll have to wait.
    • All right, mate?
    3.

    somebody you share with

  3. ​
     
    [countable] (in compounds) a person you share an activity or accommodation with
    • workmates/teammates/playmates/classmates
    • my room-mate/flatmate
    see also age-mate, running mate, soulmate

    4. bird/animal

  4. ​
     
    [countable] the sexual partner of a bird or animal
    • A male bird sings to attract a mate.
    Topics Birdsb2, Animalsb2

    5. sexual partner

  5. ​[countable] (informal) a husband, wife or other sexual partner
    • Many matchmaking sites compile lists of potential mates using basic information.
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • potential
    • prospective
    • ideal
    • …
    verb + mate
    • attract
    • find
    • choose
    • …
    See full entry
    6.

    job

  6. ​[countable] (British English) a person whose job is to help a worker who has had training in a skill
    • a builder’s/plumber’s mate
    7.

    on ship

  7. ​[countable] an officer in a commercial ship below the rank of captain or master see also first mateTopics Transport by waterc2

    8. in chess

  8. ​
    (also checkmate)
     [uncountable] (in chess) a position in which one player cannot prevent their king (= the most important piece) being captured and therefore loses the game
  9. ​
    (also checkmate)
     [uncountable] a situation in which somebody has been completely defeated
    10. Word Originnoun senses 1 to 7 late Middle English: from Middle Low German māt(e) ‘comrade’, of West Germanic origin; related to meat (the underlying concept was of eating together). noun sense 8 Middle English: the noun from Anglo-Norman French mat (from the phrase eschec mat ‘checkmate’); the verb from Anglo-Norman French mater ‘to checkmate’.
See mate in the Oxford Advanced American DictionarySee mate in the Oxford Learner's Dictionary of Academic English

name: mate
content:
mate

verb
 
 
/meɪt/
 
/meɪt/
Verb Forms
present simple I / you / we / they mate
 
/meɪt/
 
/meɪt/
he / she / it mates
 
/meɪts/
 
/meɪts/
past simple mated
 
/ˈmeɪtɪd/
 
/ˈmeɪtɪd/
past participle mated
 
/ˈmeɪtɪd/
 
/ˈmeɪtɪd/
-ing form mating
 
/ˈmeɪtɪŋ/
 
/ˈmeɪtɪŋ/
jump to other results

    animals/birds

  1. ​
     
    [intransitive] mate (with something) (of two animals or birds) to have sex in order to produce young
    • Do foxes ever mate with dogs?
    • After mating, the female kills the male.
    • Females that mate with several males are rare.
    • the sexual signal from the adult female that tells the male she is ready to mate
    see also matingTopics Animalsb2, Birdsb2
  2. ​[transitive] mate something (to/with something) to put animals or birds together so that they will have sex and produce young

    3. in chess

  3. ​
    (also checkmate)
     [transitive] (in chess) to put your opponent in a position in which they cannot prevent their king (= the most important piece) being captured and therefore lose the game
  4. ​
    (also checkmate)
     [transitive] to defeat somebody completely
    5. Word Originverb senses 1 to 2 late Middle English: from Middle Low German māt(e) ‘comrade’, of West Germanic origin; related to meat (the underlying concept was of eating together). verb sense 3 Middle English: the noun from Anglo-Norman French mat (from the phrase eschec mat ‘checkmate’); the verb from Anglo-Norman French mater ‘to checkmate’.
See mate in the Oxford Advanced American DictionarySee mate in the Oxford Learner's Dictionary of Academic English

/ˌtʃekˈmeɪtɪd/,
 
/ˈtʃekmeɪtɪd/
 
/ˌtʃekˈmeɪtɪd/,
 
/ˈtʃekmeɪtɪd/
past participle checkmated
 
/ˌtʃekˈmeɪtɪd/,
 
/ˈtʃekmeɪtɪd/
 
/ˌtʃekˈmeɪtɪd/,
 
/ˈtʃekmeɪtɪd/
-ing form checkmating
 
/ˌtʃekˈmeɪtɪŋ/,
 
/ˈtʃekmeɪtɪŋ/
 
/ˌtʃekˈmeɪtɪŋ/,
 
/ˈtʃekmeɪtɪŋ/
jump to other results
  1. ​checkmate somebody/something (in chess) to put your opponent in a position in which they cannot prevent their king (= the most important piece) being captured and therefore lose the game
    • His king had been checkmated.
  2. ​to defeat somebody completely
    • She hoped the plan would checkmate her opponents.

name: age-mate
content:
age-mate

noun
 
/ˈeɪdʒ meɪt/
 
/ˈeɪdʒ meɪt/
jump to other results
  1. ​a person of the same age or belonging to the same age group
    • Siblings and age-mates commonly lived together.
    • The toddlers participated in playgroups with age-mates.

name: running mate
content:
running mate

noun
 
/ˈrʌnɪŋ meɪt/
 
/ˈrʌnɪŋ meɪt/
 [usually singular] (politics)
jump to other results
  1. ​(in the US) a person who is chosen by the candidate in an election, especially that for president, to support them and to have the next highest political position if they win
    • The presidential nominee was advised to choose a woman as a running mate.

    • congress
